docs.lead_paragraph: THOSE who think that the cuisine of Thailand is little more than foods seasoned with tongue-scorching spices served with a lot of rice will be pleased to stand corrected. This Far Eastern cuisine incorporates into its own culinary tradition the curries of India and the Chinese knack of contrasting and balancing texture and flavor and of cooking foods quickly. The flavors that give Thai food its distinctive edge come from such ingredients as fragrant coriander, lime, lemon grass, a range of chilies and nam pla (a fermented fish sauce), used alone or teamed with neuturalizing peanut sauce, coconut milk or cucumber. Whatever combination, the result adds up to a cuisine deliciously complex and engaging. Thai cuisine has been slow in finding its way to the county, but now Reka's, newly opened in a small, unassuming block of shops just an arm's length away from busy Route 6, brings a respectable representation of the tastes of Siam. Thai objects decorate the showcase entrance and include a low dining table, cushions, a gilded cart, tusks, carvings and books. Beyond, the dining room walls reveal only a trace of their pizza parlor past under a lamina of Thai decorations. Glass table tops protect crocheted coverings, some with soiled edges, from further mishaps.

docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO AMERICA is flexing its gastronomic muscles, and nowhere is this more obvious than in California. Here, where chefs are as glamorous as movie stars and today's new dish is tomorrow's discard, preoccupation with the latest food trends surpasses most other leisure- time activity. But innovation, which has led to much-admired and often-copied creations, is, unfortunately, often practiced for its own sake. Freshness is the cornerstone of the cooking style that has been dubbed California Cuisine, which, despite its faddist tendencies, is remarkably straightforward. But, as was clear from a recent two-week visit to this state, there are a number of other characteristics, among them the following: * Grilling, especially with mesquite. * Combining cuisines that scarcely had a nodding acquaintance before, such as Japanese and French.

docs.lead_paragraph: THERE was a murmur of conversation in the group watching Claire Wagner line a charlotte mold. Mrs. Wagner looked up, a frown crossing her brow beneath stern blond bangs, and admonished sharply: "Mesdames, il faut parler francais. Ne trichez-pas!" One of the students, Mildred Netreba, whispered; "I wasn't cheating; to her, my French sounds like English."

docs.lead_paragraph: THREE years ago I traveled to Japan to judge an international cooking test for a Tokyo television station. One of the dishes entered by the Swiss team contained something called sprouted lentils. I had never heard of them and after tasting - they were delicious - wondered aloud why we couldn't find something like them in America. ''Give me time,'' came the immediate reply from a young, American-born member of that team, Michael Romano. He didn't need much time at that. Today, Michael Romano, 33 years old, is a master chef, expert in preparing updated versions of classic French cuisine. He may also be the youngest American chef to head the kitchen of a luxury French restaurant, La Caravelle, considered by many to be one of the top French restaurants in New York City.

byline.original: By ROBERT LINDSEY; ROBERT LINDSEY is chief of The Times bureau in Los Angeles

docs.lead_paragraph: Florida has oranges and stone crabs, New York, lox and bagels. Louisiana has Cajun-style blackfish and Creole gumbo. Maine has lobster. Only California, with its customary modesty, claims to have invented, along with France and Italy, an entire cuisine. Not many years ago, California cuisine meant a hamburger, fries and a milk shake at a drive-in restaurant. But thanks largely to the seminal influence of two people, Alice Waters, founder of Chez Panisse in Berkeley, and Wolfgang Puck, the proprietor-chef of Spago in West Hollywood, California has produced a still-evolving culinary style that can be sampled from one end of the state to the other. It's a style that emphasizes fresh, local ingredients cooked simply. Menus change according to the season and the availability of produce, seafood and herbs. At many restaurants, patrons may find as much attention devoted to a well-prepared salad as to more elaborate dishes.

headline.kicker: JEAN TROISGROS, A TOP CHEF, DIES

docs.lead_paragraph: Jean Troisgros, one of France's most influential chefs, died today of a heart attack while playing tennis at a hotel in Vittel, a spa in eastern France. He was 56 years old. The death was reported by friends and associates here and was confirmed in New York City by his daughter-in- law, Martine, wife of Mr. Troisgros's son, Georges, who is a chef at Manhattan's Lut ece restaurant. Mr. Troisgros's brother and partner, Pierre, was reported to be on vacation in Egypt and unavailable for comment. For the first time, the restaurant was closed for a two-week summer vacation.
